newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Canadian Mountie in Indonesia for Busang probe.
newsitem.headline: Canadian Mountie in Indonesia for Busang probe.

text.p: A member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) arrived in Indonesia on Thursday to discuss investigations into the Busang gold fiasco with the government, a Canadian diplomat said.
"We have an RCMP liaison officer accredited to Indonesia. He's based in Singapore, he's come in here now," diplomat Rene Cremonese said.
"The idea will be he will have preliminary discussions with Indonesian authorities on the Bre-X issue," Cremonese said. "There is no one coming in at the moment from Canada."

Brigadier-General Ahwil Luthan, secretary of Indonesia's National Central Bureau which handles investigations requiring Interpol assistance, said on Wednesday he would hold talks with the RCMP officer on Friday.

An independent report released on Sunday concluded the once-fabled Busang gold site in Indonesia's East Kalimantan province in Borneo, contained no gold worth mining and said data had been falsified on a massive and unprecedented scale.

The RCMP said in Alberta on Wednesday it had received two complaints of fraud concerning Busang, which was discovered by Canadian exploration company Bre-X Minerals Ltd. Bre-X is based in Calgary, Alberta.
In a letter to the RCMP, Bre-X chief executive David Walsh alleged a fraud had been perpetrated against his company, but he did not identify a suspect.

A second fraud complaint was filed by the Ontario Securities Commission (OSC), Canada's top securities regulator. The Ontario Securities Commission is conducting its own investigation of Bre-X for possible violations of insider trading and disclosure laws.
Luthan said his department had begun gathering evidence of possible commercial crime over Busang, which at one point was touted as one of the biggest gold finds this century.
"We have asked for information from the Ministry of Mines and Energy and it is expected to come through the national police department," he said.
"We are gathering evidence...from the death of the Filipino geologist (Michael de Guzman)...it starts from there."
De Guzman, chief geologist of Bre-X, fell to his death from a helicopter on his way to the Busang gold property in March.
One week after de Guzman's death, Bre-X's Busang partner Freeport McMoRan Copper and Gold Inc announced that its test drillings at the property showed "insignificant" amounts of gold.

An independent audit of Busang has since confirmed Freeport's findings. Consultant Strathcona Mineral Services Ltd said in its report that data on the Busang property had been falsified on a scale "without precedent in mining history".

Bre-X held 45 percent of Busang, Freeport 15 percent and Indonesian interests the rest. The Indonesian government held a 10 percent stake and the Nusamba Group, linked to President Suharto, held 30 percent along with a local partner.
All the partners have now withdrawn from the Busang project.
Luthan said it was possible the RCMP officer would interview the local partners for more information about Busang, but added no final schedule had been drawn up.
